LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
Borrower  Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
   
The Proposal  The  proposal  comprises  a  proposed  loan  of  $35  million  for 
subprogram II of the Second Financial Sector Program Loan (FSPL 
II). FSPL II takes a cluster approach and consists of two back-to-
back  subprograms.  Implementation  of  FSPL  II—subprogram  I  is 
scheduled for completion in December 2004. 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Financial Sector 
Subsector: Nonbanking 
Themes:  Sustainable  economic  growth,  Governance,  and  Pivate 
sector development 
   
Environment  Category C. 
Assessment  The  environmental  implications  were  reviewed  and  no  significant 
adverse impact was identified.

The Program   Viet Nam’s financial sector mirrors its economy and is in transition. 
Rationale  The  Government  has  made  persistent  efforts  to  modernize  and 
transform  the  financial  sector,  recognizing  its  significance  to  the 
country’s  economic  performance.  Still,  plagued  by  many  factors 
inherited from the former regime, the formal financial system remains 
underdeveloped, inefficient, and inaccessible to many. 
 
Financial intermediation is low, and is dominated by bank savings 
and  loans.  The  banking  system—with  its  high  levels  of 
nonperforming  loans—is  unable  to  fully  support  economic 
development  and  generate  employment.  The  Government  has 
initiated the process for financial and operational restructuring of the 
banking subsector with assistance from the International Monetary 
Fund (IMF) and World Bank under the poverty reduction and growth 
facility (PRGF) and poverty reduction support credit (PRSC) in June 
2001.  FSPL  II  was  formulated  to  complement  this  process.  It 
specifically addresses the need to develop alternative channels of 
financial intermediation to support Viet Nam’s broad-based economic 
growth  and  socioeconomic  development  objectives,  including 
poverty reduction. 
 
The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Board approved the cluster 
concept of FSPL II and subprogram I for $50 million from the Asian 
Development  Fund  (ADF)  on  20  November  2002.  Subprogram  I 
achieved  concrete  outputs  and  all  subprogram  I  second-tranche 
release conditions had been fully or substantially complied with by

iii 
October 2004. The Government has shown solid commitment to the 
reform program and is ready to continue with subprogram II.    
 
FSPL II—subprogram II, building on achievements of subprogram I, 
will  continue  to  support  the  Government’s  effort  to  develop 
alternative channels of financial intermediation such as money and 
capital markets, insurance, leasing, and financial infrastructure to 
enhance  public  confidence.  The  nonbanking  subsector  and  the 
capital market will provide long-term funds and investment capital 
that are largely lacking in Viet Nam. Higher efficiency may be 
achieved  through  increased  competition  from  the  nonbanking 
subsector. The financial system as a whole will be broader, better 
balanced, and more resilient to external shocks. 
   
Objective and  The objective is to support the Government’s efforts to enable the 
Scope  development  of  alternative  channels  of  market-based  financial 
intermediation.  Necessary  components  include  (i)  economic 
policies  conducive  to  sound  and  vibrant  financial  sector 
development;  (ii)  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks  that  will 
promote innovation and healthy competition while monitoring and 
reducing systemic risks; (iii) regulators with the authority, budget, 
skills,  and  established  procedures  to  monitor  and  enforce 
regulations; and (iv) supporting financial infrastructure. 
 
To achieve the objective, the FSPL II focuses on 
(i)  establishing a regulatory framework for insurance business, 
strengthening  the  supervisory  and  regulatory  frameworks, 
and promoting the development of key professionals; 
(ii)  promoting  the  leasing  industry  by  creating  a  coherent
regulatory  framework,  establishing  ground  rules  for  contract 
enforcement, and enhancing public awareness; 
(iii)  enabling interbank and money market development through 
phased  interest  rate  deregulation,  more  money  market 
instruments,  and  increased  development  of  the  market 
microstructure; 
(iv)  fostering the capital markets’ financial intermediation by (a) 
establishing  incentives  compatible  with  the  regulatory 
framework  for  increasing  quality  shares  trading  on  the 
securities market, (b) strengthening market surveillance, and 
(c) building the basis for institutional investors; and 
(v)  continuing  to  support  financial  infrastructure  such  as  the 
accounting  and  auditing  systems,  a  secured  transactions 
system, a deposit insurance system (assisted under FSPL I), 
and the beginnings of an anti-money-laundering regime.

iv   
Loan Amount and Terms  Subprogram II of FSPL II will comprise a loan to be drawn from the 
ADF that will have a repayment period of 24 years, including a grace 
period of 8 years, and carry an interest rate of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter. Subprogram 
II of FSPL II is also proposed to be cofinanced by Agence Française 
de Développement (AFD) for €12 million. 
   
Program Period and   The loan for subprogram II of $35 million will be released in three 
Tranches  tranches: (i) $10 million upon fulfillment of specified first tranche 
release conditions, (ii) $15 million subject to fulfillment of specified
second  tranche  release  conditions,  and  (iii)  $10  million  after 
completion  of  specified  third  tranche  release  conditions. 
Implementation of subprogram II is planned for 1 April 2005 to 1 
April 2007. 
   
Executing Agency  The  State  Bank  of  Viet  Nam  (SBV)  will  continue  to  be  the 
Executing  Agency  for  subprogram  II.  To  coordinate  program 
implementation  among  government  ministries  and  agencies 
concerned,  a  program  steering  committee  (PSC)  has  been 
formed.  The  PSC,  chaired  by  a  deputy  governor  of  SBV, 
comprises  senior  officers  from  all  ministries  and  government 
agencies concerned. The PSC will continue to meet twice yearly 
and on an ad-hoc basis to review pending issues and propose 
concrete actions to resolve them, thus ensuring timely program 
implementation. A program implementation and coordination unit, 
formed  within  SBV  and  headed  by  a  senior  SBV  officer,  will 
continue to assist ADB and the PSC in implementation. 
   
Procurement  The proceeds of the FSPL II—subprogram II will be disbursed for 
a broad range of imports, subject to a negative list of ineligible 
items. All procurement of goods and services produced in and 
originating from ADB member countries will be made with due 
consideration  to  economy  and  efficiency,  in  accordance  with 
standard public sector procedures in Viet Nam and normal private 
sector commercial practices acceptable to ADB. The Borrower will 
certify  that  the  value  of  total  imports  minus  (i)  imports  from 
nonmember  countries,  (ii)  ineligible  imports,  and  (iii) 
disbursements made under other official development assistance 
is greater than the amount expected to be disbursed during the 
year. ADB will have the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds 
and to verify the accuracy of the Borrower's certification. 
   
Counterpart Funds  The policy framework for FSPL II includes specific components 
that bear distinct costs of structural adjustments. The counterpart 
funds to be generated from loan proceeds will be used to finance 
the structural adjustment costs arising from FSPL II.

v 
Risks and Safeguards  FSPL II faces three principal risks. The first is the resurfacing of 
sociopolitical pressure that could delay reform. Materialization of 
this risk is contingent on economic performance. Judging from the 
current status of the economy and its outlook—as well as pro-
reform statements and achievements made by the Government 
with full public support—this risk is currently limited. Nevertheless, 
macroeconomic conditions and the sociopolitical situation will be 
closely monitored against program objectives. 
 
The second risk relates to progress in restructuring state-owned 
banks and state-owned enterprises (SOEs), both of which weigh 
heavily on Viet Nam’s financial sector. Many technical difficulties 
remain, and slower-than-expected progress has had implications 
on achieving the objectives of FSPL II. However, the momentum 
building toward carrying out the reform process is strong within 
the Government. The comprehensive frameworks that the World 
Bank  developed  under  the  PRSC  for  restructuring  banks  and 
SOEs, as well as associated technical assistance from bilateral 
agencies,  will  provide  the  necessary  technical  support.  ADB's 
close coordination with IMF and the World Bank will continue, in 
order  to  synchronize  the  subsectoral  reform  measures  and 
achieve the full benefits of FSPL II.  
 
The third risk pertains to the technical capacities of implementing 
agencies. The Government’s track record suggests that, given 
adequate  technical  support,  its  commitment  to  undertake  the 
proposed reforms is strong. In implementing subprogram I, for 
example, delays were predominantly a result of a lack of technical 
expertise  in  the  financial  sector,  particularly  for  drafting  laws, 
rules,  and  regulations.  The  delays  were  exacerbated  by  the 
consensus building approach taken for their enactment, requiring 
interministerial coordination. To reduce this risk, comprehensive 
discussions were undertaken with the implementing agencies and 
the ongoing technical assistance (TA) for capacity building will 
tackle the technical difficulties anticipated with implementing the 
policy actions proposed under FSPL II.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for subprogram II of the Financial Sector Program Loan II 
(FSPL II). 
 
II.  BACKGROUND 
2.  On 20 November 2002, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Board approved FSPL II,1 
(i) the cluster concept of 3 subprograms for $75 million, and (ii) subprogram I for $50 million 
from the Asian Development Fund (ADF) to be released in two tranches: one of $20 million and 
one of $30 million. The program’s objective is to support the Government’s efforts in building an 
enabling  environment  for  alternative  channels  of  market-based  financial  intermediation. 
Alternative financial intermediation is becoming increasingly important for Viet Nam, whose 
financial sector remains dominated by bank savings and loans. The banking sector alone, with 
its high-level of nonperforming loans and planned restructuring, cannot support the economy in 
achieving its potential gross domestic product (GDP) growth, nor can it generate employment 
for the expanding labor force. Necessary components for an enabling environment include (i) 
economic policies conducive to sound and vibrant financial sector development; (ii) legal and 
regulatory frameworks that will promote innovation and healthy competition while monitoring 
and reducing systemic risks, (iii) regulators with the authority, budget, skills, and established 
procedures to monitor and enforce regulations, and (iv) support for financial infrastructure.  
 
3.  To achieve these objectives, FSPL II focuses on (i) establishing a regulatory framework 
for  the  insurance  industry,  strengthening  the  supervisory  and  regulatory  frameworks  and 
promoting the development of key professionals; (ii) promoting the leasing industry by creating a 
coherent  regulatory  framework,  establishing  ground  rules  for  contract  enforcement,  and 
enhancing  public  awareness;  (iii)  enabling  interbank  and  money  market  development  by 
gradually deregulating interest rates, increasing the number of money market instruments, and 
developing the market microstructure; (iv) fostering capital market financial intermediation by (a) 
establishing incentives compatible with the regulatory framework for increasing the number of 
quality shares on the market, (b) strengthening market surveillance, and (c) building the basis 
for participation by institutional investors; and (v) continuing to build financial infrastructure such 
as accounting and auditing systems, secured transactions system, a deposit insurance system, 
and an anti-money-laundering regime. (The logical framework is in Appendix 1 and summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 2.) 
 
4.  Subprogram I was envisioned to be completed within 15 months from loan effectiveness. 
Subprograms II and III were to be processed sequentially upon completion of the previous 
subprogram and completed within 12 months from effectiveness of each proceeding loan. The 
cluster  approach  provides  the  opportunity  to  refine  proposed  policy  actions  of  succeeding 
subprograms  in  order  to  reflect  the  Government's  achievements,  the  changing  policy 
environment,  and  lessons  learned  from  the  previous  subprogram.  The  program  cluster 
approach thus allows flexibility and gives leverage to implement reform measures in a dynamic 
political, economic, and financial environment. 
 
5.  FSPL II loan agreement for subprogram I was signed on 29 January 2003. An inception 
mission was fielded from 17 to 18 February 2003. The Government submitted the legal opinion

III.  MACROECONOMIC DEVELOPMENTS 
7.  Viet Nam's annual economic growth rate increased from 5.8% in 2001 to 6.4% in 2002, 
and 7.1% in 2003. Growth in the industrial and construction sector was 8.9% in 2002 and 9.6% 
in 2003. Faster-paced economic growth has caused inflation to rise. The consumer price index 
(CPI) rose from 0.8% in 2001 to an average of 3-4% in 2002 and 2003. Against the backdrop of 
robust GDP growth, fiscal and trade deficits increased, with the budget deficit widening to 4.8% 
of GDP in 2003 from 3.8% in 2002. The current account deficit rose to 5.8% of GDP in 2003 
from 2.8% in 2002. The overall macroeconomic situation is stable, however, and the fiscal 
deficit sustainable. Stable macroeconomic conditions for the past 2 years, a key precondition for 
implementing financial sector reforms, has supported FSPL II implementation. 
 
8.  The economic targets set by the National Assembly in November 2003—GDP growth of 
7.5–7.8%, a CPI increase of less than 5%, and fiscal deficit below 5% of GDP—are generally 
viewed  by  the  Government  and  the  donor  community  as  achievable.  The  macroeconomic 
environment carries no immediate risks to FSPL II implementation. However, the relatively low 
level of financial intermediation continues and the nonbanking sector—specifically the insurance 
sector  and  the  capital  markets,  the  two  main  components  of  FSPL  II—have  gained  their 
relevance as important means of domestic savings mobilization. 
 
9.   Viet Nam is making steady progress in structural reforms. The package of tax reforms 
was approved by the National Assembly in May 2003 and has become effective as of January 
2004. The number of value-added taxes and exemptions has been reduced and the corporate 
tax rates unified for domestic and foreign-owned enterprises. Progress is also seen in Viet 
Nam's commitments toward international integration, including the bilateral trade agreement 
with the United States effective December 2001 and the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) tariff 
reductions, which are proceeding as scheduled. Viet Nam also plans to join the World Trade 
Organization (WTO) in 2005. On the other hand, implementation of critical reforms planned for 
large  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  and  the  four  major  state-owned  commercial  banks 
(SOCBs) have been slower than expected, with implications for the money and capital market 
components of FSPL II. Accelerating privatization and listing of large SOEs would bring the 
much-needed increase in supply of securities to the Ho Chi Minh Securities Trading Center 
(STC).  Stronger  pressure  on  SOCBs  to  improve  profitability  would  also  encourage  more 
transactions on the secondary money market.

IV.  FSPL II SUBPROGRAM I—STATUS OF IMPLEMENTATION 
A.  Status of Subprogram I Second Tranche Release Policy Actions  
10.  In  line  with  the  objectives  of  FSPL  II,  the  Government  adopted  legal,  policy,  and 
institutional measures under subprogram I. Many measures required extensive coordination to 
ascertain stakeholders' understanding, acceptance, and actual adoption. Of the 17 subprogram 
I second tranche release conditions, 15 have been fully complied with and 2 substantially 
complied with (Appendix 3).  
 
11.  The  insurance  component  under  subprogram  I  had  seven  second  tranche  release 
conditions,  three  of  which  are  in  support  of  creating  equal  opportunities  to  enhance 
competitiveness of the insurance market. 
 
(i)  The Ministry of Finance to adopt a simple and transparent approval system 
for changes in the operation of insurance companies (complied with). 
 
12.  The revised Circular 71, issued by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) as Circular 98 on 15 
October 2004, streamlines the approval system for changes in the operation of insurance 
companies, opening of new branches, and introduction of new products, reducing considerably 
the time and steps required for obtaining MOF clearance. 
 
(ii)  The Ministry of Finance to continue to grant licenses for insurance brokers, 
regardless  of  the  ownership  form,  to  enhance  competitiveness  in  the 
brokerage business (complied with). 
 
13.  The number of licensed insurance brokers rose from one state-owned company in 2001 
to five, including one foreign-owned company and several joint-stock companies, by the end of 
September 2004. 
 
(iii)  The  Ministry  of  Finance  to  specify  incentive  measures  for  insurance 
companies to develop new insurance products, especially for products in 
support  of  agricultural,  forestry,  and  fisheries  activities  (substantially 
complied with). 
 
14.  MOF awarded additional incentives to promote industry segments that have experienced 
substantial  losses  for  insurers  and  led  to  withdrawal  of  insurance  products.  To  develop 
agricultural insurance, for example, MOF licensed Groupama, a French insurance company, to 
establish a 100%-foreign-owned, non-life insurance company and gave it preferential treatments 
in terms of agents' commissions and operational scope. General guidelines on incentives will 
need to be prepared in future. Such guidelines, however, will require rigorous actuarial studies 
and cost/benefit analyses. 
 
15.  There  are  three  subprogram  I  second  tranche  release  conditions  for  strengthening 
supervision and prudential regulations of the insurance sector. 
 
(iv)  The Ministry of Finance to adopt procedures for onsite inspection and off-
site surveillance for insurance companies (complied with).

enforcement of sanctions for administrative offences in the management and usage of licenses, 
assignment of insurance contracts, unlawful competitive action, forced purchase of insurance, 
breaches in provisions on reserve requirements, appropriation, management and usage of 
operational reserves, investment of capital, and financial prudence. 
 
19.  The last of the seven subprogram I second tranche release conditions for the insurance

(vii)  The Ministry of Finance to endorse plans for development of actuaries and

Preparation is also underway for establishing the insurance training program for insurance 
regulators at the Finance Institute. Agence Française de Développement (AFD), cofinancier of 
FSPL II, is supporting training of trainers to ensure quality of programs being offered at the 
Finance Institute.

B.  Program Implementation  
1.  Insurance and Leasing Sectors 
39.  FSPL II supports development of the nonbanking subsector, represented by insurance 
and leasing, both of which are at the early stages of development. While the two industries are 
small, their growth has been exceptional. During subprogram I implementation, steady progress 
was made in putting in place the necessary legal and regulatory frameworks for building an 
environment to support the sound development of insurance and leasing. 
 
    a.   Insurance Sector 
 
40.  FSPL II aims to promote the sound development of the insurance sector by supporting 
the Government in (i) creating a competitive business environment, (ii) enhancing corporate 
governance of insurance companies, (iii) strengthening supervision and prudential regulations, 
and (iv) developing insurance sector infrastructure. The Government, as a first step toward 
meeting these objectives, upgraded the insurance management division to department status in 
August 2003 and strengthened its supervisory capacity. MOF also hosted the 6th Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Insurance Regulators’ Meeting and the ASEAN Council of 
Insurance Meeting from 19 to 23 August 2003. The meeting had more than 80 participants and 
concluded  with  an  agreement  on  concrete  measures  for  cooperation  among  insurance 
supervisors. Viet Nam, as the host country, presented thematic reports on the liberalization 
process of financial services in ASEAN countries and the initial results of opening up Viet Nam’s 
insurance market to foreign companies.

8   
41.  During implementation of FSPL II—subprogram I, several deregulatory measures were 
adopted to create a competitive environment for financial services (paras. 11-14), strengthening 
supervision  and  prudential  regulations  (paras.  15-18)  and  developing  insurance  sector 
infrastructure (paras. 19-20).  
 
42.  Recent  achievements  for  improving  corporate  governance  in  the  insurance  sector 
include  Decision  175/2003/QD-TTg  issued  by  the  prime  minister  approving  the  2003-2010 
insurance market development strategy. The strategy addresses, in a phased manner, some of 
the  major  corporate  governance  issues  in  the  insurance  sector.  The  ownership  and 
management of the state-owned insurance companies were reviewed and Bao Viet, the largest 
state-owned  insurance  company,  will  be  transformed  into  a  one-member  limited  liability 
company  operating  under  the  Enterprise  Law.  In  accordance  with  the  strategy,  the  prime 
minister endorsed equitization of two other state-owned insurers: HCMC Insurance Company 
(Bao Minh) and Vietnam Reinsurance Company (VINARE). In July 2004, Bao Minh issued 
shares  worth  D97  billion  or  32%  of  its  equity  to  the  public  while  VINARE  is  planned  for 
equitization and listing on the Ho Chi Minh City STC by 2007. Although the majority stake will 
remain with the state, concrete steps forward have been made toward privatization of the state-
owned insurance companies. 
 
    b.  Leasing Sector 
 
43.  To support the emergent leasing sector, FSPL II addresses two critical issues: (i) the 
regulatory environment is not conducive to business development, and lacks clear ground rules 
for contract enforcement; and (ii) public awareness of the leasing industry is inadequate. With 
SBV’s solid commitment to developing the sector, progress was made not only in adopting 
measures to fulfill FSPL II policy actions but also to enhance the operating environment for the 
sector.  
 
44.  A second tranche release policy action under subprogram I, requiring consultation with 
various government ministries and agencies, was fulfilled by October 2003 (paras. 21-22). The 
Government has taken actions to improve the environment for business development. These 
include  (i)  issuance of  a  new  regulation  facilitating  the  opening  of  new  branches,  and  (ii) 
streamlined tax system for financial leases under Circular 24 issued by MOF on 20 March 2003. 
SBV is also revising the decree and circular on leasing and is scheduled to submit them to the 
Government in early 2005. The revised decree will contain provisions on methods to deal with 
leased assets in cases of default on lease contracts (policy action subprogram III, B. 1). SBV, 
MOJ, and the Peoples' Supreme Court are involved in discussions on regulations, procedures, 
and methods to deal with leased assets in the case of default.  
 
45.  To promote public awareness of leasing, as well as capacity building for those engaged 
in leasing, conferences with leasing professionals from other developing countries were held in 
Hanoi and HCMC on 25 and 27 August 2004, respectively. The conferences were successful in 
promoting better public awareness of leasing, as well as in demonstrating SBV's commitment to 
developing the sector. 
 
2.  Money and Capital Markets 
46.  FSPL II also supports development of the money and capital markets. The overall 
development of the two markets was constrained by slower-than-expected progress in SOCB 
and  SOE  restructuring.  Nevertheless,  steady  progress  was  made  during  subprogram  I  in

implementing the necessary legal and regulatory frameworks for expanding the role of the two 
markets within the financial sector. 
 
    a.  Interbank and Money Market 
 
47.  FSPL  II  supports  the  Government's  initiative  to  develop  the  interbank  and  money 
markets by focusing on (i) deregulating interest rates, (ii) developing money market instruments, 
(iii) improving the market structure, and (iv) enhancing the treasury function and capacity of 
SOCBs. Availability of money market instruments has increased as a result of a regulation 
allowing the issuance of negotiable certificates of deposit (a first tranche release condition under 
subprogram  I),  regularized  issuance  of  short-term  treasury  bills  by  MOF  and  issuance  of 
regulations on repurchase agreements (second tranche release conditions under subprogram I, 
paras. 23-25). 
 
48.  To further develop money market instruments, FSPL II also supports an integrated legal 
framework that will allow for growth and innovation, and proposes adoption of a negotiable 
instruments law (policy actions subprogram II, C. 2, and subprogram III, C. 1). With technical 
inputs  from  ADB  consultants  engaged  under  TA4035-VIE,  the  first  draft  of  the  negotiable 
instruments  law  was  completed  and  the  draft  is  currently  under  review  by  the  steering 
committee that was established on 2 April 2004 for that purpose. The committee comprises 
representatives from SBV, MOF, the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), MOJ, and the 
Government's Office. The draft law is scheduled for submission to the National Assembly for 
deliberation in 2006. Progress outside of FSPL II includes successful completion of the first 
phase of a World-Bank-funded project on modernizing the banking and payment systems. The 
system created the foundation for a national payment system, integral for development of the 
interbank and money markets. 
 
b.  Capital Market 
49.  Development  objectives  for  the  capital  market  component  of  FSPL  II  include  (i) 
broadening the capital market base, (ii) establishing a consolidated regulatory framework and 
market surveillance system (paras. 28-31, and 90), (iii) developing institutional investors (paras. 
31 and 71), (iv) developing self-regulatory organizations (para. 72), and (v) enhancing market 
microstructure. Solid steps forward were taken in all five areas during FSPL II—subprogram I.  
 
50.  In order to broaden the capital market base, FSPL II supports measures to link the SOE 
equitization program and STC listing through adoption of a list of SOEs as candidates for listing 
(policy action subprogram II, D. 1). In 2003 the Steering Committee on Enterprise Reform and 
Development (SCERD) prepared a list of 2,000 SOEs to be equitized during the next 3 years. 
The Government approved the list at the end of 2003. Among those listed, 230 SOEs have 
been identified as having chartered capital above D10 billion, thus meeting one qualification for 
listing. Furthermore, MOF is revising Decree 64 on equitization, providing tax incentives for 
listing to SOEs undergoing equitization.  
 
51.  FSPL II also supports a trading board for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) 
to further broaden the capital market (policy action subprogram II, D. 2). The prime minister 
gave approval to open the Hanoi STC for SMEs in 2002. Subsequently, SSC Chairman issued 
Decision  329/QD-UBCK  on  17  December  2003  on  the  functions,  duties,  powers,  and 
organization of the Hanoi STC and on 17 June 2004, MOF approved implementing guidelines 
for the operation of the Hanoi STC. Candidates for listing will have registered capital of D5-30

billion. The official opening of the Hanoi STC is scheduled for 2005 and as of September 2004 
approximately 10 companies have been identified for listing.3  
 
52.  Measures  taken  to  enhance  market  structure  during  subprogram  I  implementation 
include progress in establishing a centralized depository and an automated clearing/settlement 
system. In April 2004, the SSC finalized an Information Technology (IT) Master Plan, which 
includes the depository and clearing/settlement systems. The IT Master Plan also includes an 
automated surveillance system as well as a circuit breaker system based on market index. Full 
implementation of the IT system is scheduled for 2007. 
 
3.  Financial Infrastructure 
53.  FSPL  II  includes  four  components  under  financial  infrastructure  development  (i) 
strengthening the accounting and auditing system, (ii) implementing the registry for secured 
transactions system, (iii) strengthening the deposit insurance system, and (iv) developing the 
anti-money-laundering regime. 
 
a.  Accounting and Auditing System 
54.  The  accounting  and  auditing  system  is  widely  recognized  as  the  key  financial 
infrastructure, largely determining the soundness and efficiency of a market-based financial 
system. This component of FSPL II seeks to (i) establish accounting enforcement mechanisms, 
and (ii) develop a competitive accounting industry. The Accounting Law passed on 17 June 
2003 and Decrees 128 and 129 issued on 31 May 2004, providing guidelines on the Accounting 
Law, brings accounting practices significantly closer to international standards. Decree 105 on 
Independent Audit,4 issued on 30 March 2004, stipulates that all banks, insurance companies, 
listed firms, SOEs, foreign invested enterprises, and nationally important Group A projects must 
be audited by independent auditors who are fully liable for their work. Furthermore, the decree 
bans establishment of any new state-owned auditing companies and requires all currently state-
owned auditing companies and joint stock companies operating under the Enterprise Law to be 
converted into partnerships, private firms, or foreign-invested companies. The decree became 
effective on 14 April 2004. 
 
b.  Secured Transactions System 
55.  The  Government  has  made  steady  progress  toward  developing  a  nationwide, 
computerized secured transactions registration system. In 2002, registration centers for asset 
transactions were established in Hanoi and HCMC. MOJ is preparing to open a Danang office 
by end 2004. During 10 months of operations in 2003, the Hanoi registration center had 6,043 
applications to register assets, and HCMC had 6,047 applications. In the 6 months starting 
January 2004, the two centers had 4,674 and 4,423 applications, respectively. Some procedural 
issues  need  to  be  addressed,  but  pilot  testing  at  the  two  registration  centers  has  been 
successful.  A  feasibility  study  of  the  nationwide  computerized  registration  system  was 
completed and submitted to the Minister of Justice in July 2004. Following approval of the 
feasibility  study,  building  a  networked,  and  computerized,  nationwide  secured  transactions 
registration system will begin in 2005.

57.  DIV officially became operational in July 2000 under Decision 218 QD/TTg issued by the

58.  Policy actions supported under FSPL II include measures to (i) address moral hazard

auditing firms and to change the corporate structure of VACO, the country’s largest auditing 
company. One state-owned auditing firm, A&C, was equitized in accordance with Decision 
721/QB-BTC of 2 April 2003. The equitization was completed in the fourth quarter of 2003. Two 
others,  AFC  and  AASC,  are  undergoing  the  required  administrative  procedures  for 
transformation of their ownership. VACO's transformation into a one-member limited liability 
company was endorsed by the MOF under Decision 1927/QD-BTC issued on 30 June 2003 and 
the auditing firm officially became a one-member limited liability company as of 1 January 2004. 
 
B.  Lessons Learned 
75.  The Government has shown strong commitment to undertaking policy actions agreed to 
under  FSPL  II.  Throughout  FSPL  II—subprogram  I,  steady  progress  has  been  made  in 
implementing  the  overall  program  and  fulfilling  the  policy  conditions  in  line  with  program 
objectives. However, completing policy measures required significantly more time than originally 
envisioned.  Implementing  agencies  required  more  time  to  understand  concepts  and 
mechanisms that were new to the country. Furthermore, mandatory consensus building before 
actual reform implementation proved time-consuming. Technical inputs were indispensable in 
enacting rules and regulations such as the anti-money-laundering decree and revised circulars 
on accounting systems for insurance companies. The TAs ensured that best practices were 
incorporated  and  consolidated  throughout  the  consultation  period  to  achieve  the  intended 
results.  
 
76.  Fostering  a  solid  understanding  of  the  underlying  concepts  and  mechanisms  for 
modernizing the financial system and ensuring consultation with all stakeholders, including the 
private sector, are assessed as having a long-term positive impact on the sustainability of 
program outputs. Given the experience of FSPL II—subprogram I, and specifically the need for 
consensus building, more time has been allocated to meet specific policy measures for tranche 
releases under subprogram II, allowing time for consultation particularly with the relevant private 
sector stakeholders. 
 
77.  While progress was good in some areas of the Government's planned reforms, others 
confronted formidable challenges, such as those related to SOCB and SOE restructuring. For 
example, by mid-2002, most interest rates had been liberalized and the Government's priority 
shifted to developing the money market by issuing short-term treasury bills on a regular basis 
and  improving  SOCBs’  treasury  function.  FSPL  II  supports  developing  money  market 
instruments such as certificates of deposit and short-term treasury bills and improving the 
market structure by introducing money brokerage firms to penetrate through the segmented 
banking sector. However, SOCBs’ commercial orientation must significantly improve for active 
secondary  trade  on  the  money  market  to  take  place.  While  SOCBs'  operational  and 
organizational restructuring is outside the scope of FSPL II, delays in banking sector reforms 
were identified as a risk factor at the time of program formulation. This was to be mitigated

16   
through the comprehensive reform package formulated with the assistance from World Bank 
under its poverty reduction support credit (PRSC). ADB will continue to consult IMF and World 
Bank on measures to strengthen SOCBs' commercial orientation and treasury function during 
FSPL II—subprogram II. ADB's participation in PRSC would have the potential of providing an 
effective platform for developing yet closer cooperation with the World Bank and other bilateral 
donors involved in banking sector reforms. 
 
78.  SOE restructuring has also experienced delays, with a number of implications for FSPL 
II. The most prominent issue has been the quantity and quality of companies listed on the 
HCMC  STC.  FSPL  II—subprogram  II  has  two  policy  measures  under  the  capital  market 
component for increasing the number of listed state-owned enterprises. One policy measure 
calls for SCERD, in cooperation with SSC, to issue a list of SOEs that are candidates for listing 
(policy action subprogram II, D. 1). The second policy action requires companies meeting listing 
criteria to disclose the same information as listed companies in order to prevent regulatory 
arbitrage (policy action subprogram II, D. 3). An assessment of SOE restructuring concluded 
that proposing policy actions to complement the latest developments in SOE reform would be 
more meaningful. As consensus on the broad framework on SOE restructuring is established, 
targeting  a specific  group  of  SOEs  to  move  forward,  and  possibly  to  list,  would  be  more 
relevant.  The  two  FSPL  II—subprogram  II  policy  actions  relating  to  listing  of  SOEs  and 
disclosure of information have therefore been refined (paras. 88-90). 
   
C.  Refined Policy Framework and Actions for Subprogram II 
79.  The Government requested to combine FSPL II—subprograms II and III (in accordance 
with paragraph 94 of FSPL II RRP) during the 2004 country programming mission (12-27 April 
2004). The request was made on the basis of (i) relatively small loan sizes, and (ii) more 
certainty in completing specific policy actions. 
 
80.  FSPL  II—subprograms  II  and  III  are  proposed  to  be  consolidated  into  a  single 
subprogram with three tranches. In formulating the subprogram, all policy actions proposed 
under the FSPL II cluster were discussed with the Government. Essentially all policy actions 
that  were  proposed  in  subprograms  II  and  III  have  been  maintained.  (For  details  see 
Refinements under Proposed Subprogram II in Appendix 4.)  
 
81.  Under the insurance component, proposed revisions comprise (i) exclusion of one policy 
action on an approval system for opening new branches and representative offices of insurance 
companies, (ii) replacing one policy action for strengthening corporate governance with two 
policy  actions  specifically  addressing  concerns  of  the  current  operations  of  the  insurance 
industry, (iii) adding one policy action on strengthening supervision and prudential regulation, 
and (iv) adding a new policy action on enhancing industry professionals. 
 
82.  Under the capital markets component, a policy action for broadening the capital market 
base and another policy action for establishing a consolidated regulatory framework have been 
refined to better reflect developments in SOE restructuring and progress in the Government's 
plans to upgrade the legal framework of the capital market.  
 
83.  Under the component for improving the financial infrastructure, minor refinements have 
been made for establishing the secured transactions systems and strengthening the deposit 
insurance corporation, taking into account the progress made by the Government and specific 
bottlenecks found during FSPL II—subprogram I implementation. In terms of preventing money

17 
laundering, more specificity have been added to the policy action on establishing the financial 
intelligence unit, reflecting the Government's advanced understanding of the requirements. 
 
84.  A complete set of reforms to be implemented in FSPL II—subprogram II is in the Policy 
Matrix (Appendix 5). Policy actions that have been refined or added to reflect the Government's 
achievements,  the  evolving  policy  environment,  and  lessons  learned  from  subprogram  I 
implementation are discussed in detail below.  
 
1.  Insurance Sector 
85.  Policy actions under the insurance component were revised to consider the sector’s 
growth, which has given rise to the need to strengthen corporate governance and prudential 
regulations. The policy action proposed for development and introduction of an approval system 
for opening new branches and representative offices of insurance companies and insurance 
brokers (policy action subprogram II, A. 1) was sufficiently covered under the revised Circular 71 
and is excluded from the newly formulated FSPL II—subprogram II.   
 
86.  To strengthen corporate governance, a policy action requiring MOF to submit a plan to 
the Government to improve corporate governance, including ownership structure of state-owned 
insurance companies and joint stock insurance companies (policy action subprogram III, A. 3), 
is replaced by two policy actions. The two new policy actions address specific concerns of the 
current operations within the insurance industry. The first is the lack of reliability of annual 
accounts, and the second is the absence of institutional frameworks to monitor and control risks 
inherent to the sector. The newly formulated FSPL II—subprogram II policy actions proposes to 
enhance corporate governance of insurance companies by MOF by (i) requiring insurance 
companies to  have  the  annual  accounts cosigned  by  an  MOF  authorized  auditor;  and  (ii) 
recommending that insurance companies adopt compliance manuals and establish compliance 
committees,  audit  committees,  and  risk  management  committees  by  holding  seminars, 
workshops, and publishing reference materials on MOF’s web site. 
 
87.  To strengthen supervision and prudential regulations, a policy condition has been added 
encouraging MOF to introduce regulations requiring signoff of reserves in the annual accounts 
by  an  actuary  approved  by  MOF.  A  policy  action  mandating  that  at  least  50%  of  MOF’s 
Insurance Department staff complete insurance-related courses at the Finance Institute or other 
MOF-recognized institutes is now included under FSPL II—subprogram II. 
 
2.  Capital Market 
88.  Two policy actions under the capital markets component have been refined to ensure 
that concrete actions are taken toward meeting the program objectives of broadening the capital 
market base and establishing a consolidated regulatory framework. The two original policy 
actions are (i) the SCERD, in cooperation with SSC, issue a list of SOEs that are candidates for 
listing (policy action subprogram II, D.1); and (ii) MPI, together with SSC, require joint-stock 
companies  that  meet  listing  requirements  to  disclose  the  same  information  as  the  listed 
companies to the National Business Information Center (policy action subprogram II, D.3).  
 
89.  SCERD has prepared a list of more than 200 companies with registered capital of more 
than D10 billion as candidates for listing, but whether these companies will actually list is 
uncertain. The Government has prepared concrete plans for SOE equitization. However, the 
option to list must be considered by the SOEs themselves in the process of equitization, 
particularly large SOEs with the potential to benefit from listing. To make listing attractive for

18   
SOEs, the newly formulated FSPL II—subprogram II requires that SSC, in cooperation with 
MOF, revise Decree 64 on SOE equitization to provide incentives for equitizing SOEs to list. 
 
90.  Furthermore, to consolidate the regulatory framework and surveillance system, SSC 
plans to draft a securities and exchange law for submission to the National Assembly in 2007. 
Enactment of a securities and exchange law is a welcome move given the capital markets’ 
fragmented legal framework and the limited effectiveness of a decree as a legal basis for capital 
market  operations.  SSC  is  expected  to  be  given  more  concrete  legal  power  to  undertake 
supervision, surveillance, and enforcement of laws over the securities market. To support the 
SSC in this endeavor, FSPL II—subprogram II includes a policy action to draft and submit the 
securities and exchange law to the Government which would include (i) corporate disclosure 
requirements; and (ii) supervisory, investigation, surveillance, and enforcement mechanisms. 
Disincentives for listing on the HCMC STC, such as requiring substantially more corporate 
disclosure than unlisted companies, will be addressed in a comprehensive manner under the 
securities and exchange law. 
 
3.  Financial Infrastructure 
a.  Secured Transactions System 
91.  MOJ was to continue implementing the registry of secured transactions in three other 
provinces and cities under central management on the basis of a centralized, and networked 
registration system. It was also tasked with building a national database system for secured 
transactions (policy action subprogram II, E-2. 6). FSPL II also supports MOJ in submitting a 
draft law or ordinance on registration of secured transactions to the National Assembly (policy 
action subprogram III, E-2, 2). The Government has determined that an ordinance will be issued 
for secured transactions, incorporating all procedural matters related to registration of secured 
transactions. Rather than continuing with registration system expansion, it is important for MOJ 
to take stock of all activities of current registries to improve the system and ensure that the 
ordinance submitted in 2005 supports those improvements. Accordingly, the two conditions 
were revised as follows: (i) MOJ to undertake a comprehensive review on the experience of 
operating registries and list specific measures for increasing the use of the registration system; 
and (ii) MOJ to submit a draft ordinance on registration of secured transactions to the Standing 
Committee of the National Assembly, containing all procedural requirements for registration. 
 
b.  Deposit Insurance 
92.  FSPL II also revisits the issue of phasing out people's credit funds from DIV coverage. 
The  original  policy  condition  required  the  Government  to  consider  revising  the  Decree  on 
Deposit  Insurance  to  gradually  remove  people's  credit  funds  from  DIV  coverage  once  the 
system safety fund, which will serve to cover depositors of failed people's credit funds, is fully 
operational (policy action subprogram III, E-3. 3). However, little progress has been made in 
establishing and operationalizing the system safety funds. Both DIV and SBV stressed the need 
to conduct a more detailed and pragmatic study on the different models before proceeding with 
the establishment of the system safety fund. Given the importance of this issue and the need for 
careful planning, the newly formulated FSPL II—subprogram II sequences measures to phase 
out people's credit funds in two steps: (i) to complete a feasibility study for determining the 
appropriate  model  for  depositor  protection  in  people's  credit  funds  (subprogram  II  second 
tranche release condition), and (ii) the Government to approve a funded system for depositor 
protection in people's credit funds (subprogram II third tranche release condition).

19 
c.  Anti-money Laundering  
93.  Subsequent to the issuance of the Anti-Money Laundering Decree, it was agreed that 
concrete steps should be taken to establish a financial intelligence unit. Two conditions were 
added to strengthen the anti-money-laundering component, specifically for the purposes of 
establishing and operationalizing the financial intelligence unit. The newly formulated FSPL II—
subprogram  II  supports  the  Government  in  establishing  and  operationalizing  the  financial 
intelligence unit with adequate staffing and internal procedures. The compliance programs will 
be developed in consultation with the private sector.  
 
94.  Furthermore,  the  policy  action  to  join  an  international  organization  for  anti-money-
laundering activities was upgraded to require full membership rather than observer status. 
Joining APG will help Viet Nam gain recognition from the international community as a country 
with a firm commitment to fighting money laundering and financing of terrorism. Viet Nam will 
also benefit from the contacts, information, and training provided through such an organization. 
 
D.  Subprogram II Loan Amount and Tranches 
95.  The proposed loan for FSPL II—subprogram II will comprise an ADB loan of $35 million 
equivalent from ADF. Subprogram II will be released in three tranches: (i) $10 million equivalent 
from ADF upon compliance with the first tranche conditions, (ii) $15 million equivalent from ADF 
subject to fulfillment of second tranche release conditions, and (iii) $10 million equivalent from 
ADF subject to completion of third tranche release conditions. The implementation period for 
subprogram II is proposed to be 24 months. The first tranche is expected to be released after 6 
months from loan effectiveness. Completion of policy actions for second and third tranche 
release is expected within 18 and 24 months, respectively, from loan effectiveness. 
 
96.  AFD has proposed to cofinance €35 million for FSPL II: €23 million for subprogram I and 
€12 million for subprogram II. AFD will disburse subprogram II in tranches simultaneously with 
ADB disbursements, on the same schedule and conditions. The proceeds will be disbursed to a 
special account and will be used to finance costs of projects, which are directly linked to reforms 
in the financial sector, 6 according to procedures defined between AFD and the Government. 
The  details  of  the  cofinancing  arrangement  have  been  finalized  under  a  separate  loan 
agreement between the Government and AFD.

98.  SBV will continue to be the Executing Agency for FSPL II—subprogram II. SBV, MOF,

99.  A program steering committee (PSC) was formed to coordinate program implementation 
among government ministries and agencies concerned. The PSC is chaired by the deputy 
governor  of  SBV  and  comprises  senior  officers,  duly  empowered  to  make  decisions  on 
subprogram II implementation, from ministries and government agencies including SBV, MOF, 
MPI, MOJ, SSC, and DIV. The program implementation and coordination unit has been formed 
within SBV, headed by a senior officer of SBV, and staffed with SBV officials with sufficient 
knowledge and capacity to assist the PSC and ADB. The unit will continue to be responsible for 
day-to-day implementation of subprogram II.  
 
2.  Monitoring 
100.  ADB, jointly with AFD and in cooperation with SBV, MOF, MPI, MOJ, SSC, and DIV, has 
fielded semiannual reviews to monitor the progress in FSPL II implementation and assess the 
impact on the structure and development of the financial sector. ADB jointly with AFD and the 
implementing agencies will continue to conduct semiannual reviews to ascertain the progress in 
FSPL II—subprogram II implementation and in particular to confirm compliance with tranche 
release conditions. The Government, ADB, and AFD will continue to engage in active policy 
dialogue on sector issues, reforms, and other measures and advice on actions to maintain 
FSPL II—subprogram II on course.  
 
3.  Procurement and Disbursement 
101.  In accordance with the simplified disbursement procedures and related requirements for 
program loans, all goods and services produced and originating in ADB member countries will

public procedures in Viet Nam and normal private sector commercial practices acceptable to 
ADB.8 Goods commonly traded on the international commodity markets will be procured in 
accordance with procedures appropriate to the trade and acceptable to ADB. 
 
102.  The proceeds of the FSPL II—subprogram II will be disbursed for a broad range of 
imports, except for a list of ineligible items (Appendix 6). The Borrower will certify that the value 
of total imports minus (i) imports from nonmember countries, (ii) ineligible imports, and (iii) 
disbursements made under other official development assistance, is greater than the amount 
expected to be disbursed during the year. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of the loan 
proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the Borrower's certification.
